Hmm -- I hope this email comes through in ascii.  I am sending this from Outlook Web Access.
 
-----Original Message----- 
From: Kevin Baynes [mailto:kbaynes@...] 

[KB]
I'm creating a textui.TestRunner with a PrintStream that writes to
file. I can write to the PrintStream, but TestRunner keeps printing to
the stdOut. Any ideas why it's not printing anything to the file?

[SS]
I'd call it a bug in JUnit.
 
When you call TestRunner.run(suite()) a new TestRunner is created with the default constructor.:

static public TestResult run(Test test) {
    TestRunner runner= new TestRunner();
    return runner.doRun(test);
}
 
This is the guy who actually runs your test, and he writes to System.out because  TestRunner's default constructor calls another constructor like so:

public TestRunner() {
    this(System.out);
}

  
[KB's code] 
// construct TestRunner to output all results to our log file
junit.textui.ResultPrinter printer = new junit.textui.ResultPrinter(out);
junit.textui.TestRunner    runner  = new junit.textui.TestRunner(printer);
runner.run(suite());

[SS]
So, if you run TestRunner like that, you'll always get a set of results printed to System.out. Doh!
 
You need to call the ahh, heh, creatively named TestRunner.doRun(Test suite, boolean wait) or TestRunner.doRun(Test suite) method instead.
 
A different, clunky workaround would be to do System.setOut(out) before you call run(suite()), where 'out' is your own PrintStream and make the PrintStream write to the bit bucket.
 
Hope this helps,
 
Scott Stirling
Framingham, MA
